title: Were Native Americans killed by African Americans in the 1800s? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Yes. Following the Civil War, there were four regiments of Black troops, mostly stationed on the frontier. These were the 9th and 10th Cavalry and the 24th and 25th Infantry. About 20% of the US Cavalry units fighting in the Plains Indians wars and against the Apache were these Buffalo Soldiers. They killed plenty of the enemy and lost many men as well. The units over the years had many tasks. They protected crucial roads, protected railroad surveyors, patrolled as required, fought the Apache and Comanche and Kiowa and Lakota. They garrisoned frontier forts, and in Indian Territory, tried to protect Indians from white squatters. They were involved in nearly 200 clashes with Indians There were Black people in the West in many capacities. Some of the famed Mountain Men in the fur trade were Black, most notably Jim Beckwourth, and yes, they killed Indians, and Indians killed them. Some of the other fur traders were Black, and some were slaves.

Yes… So-called ‘Buffalo Soldiers’, black troops who enlisted at the end of the Civil War. They were the first black soldiers ever deployed in peacetime by the Federal Government of the United States. Initially, ‘Buffalo Soldiers’ was the nickname given by indigenous tribes to the 10th Cavalry Regiment, but it was subsequently applied to black troops in general. Troops from several black cavalry units served in actions against the western tribes, including the Apaches during Vitorio’s War. A total of 23 Medals of Honor were awarded to black soldiers during the Indian wars. They were tough, hard-riding soldiers who were feared by their Indian foes.
